nodes.bodyText: does synchronizing here relate to removing the continues in the timer code?

The synchronizations and cancel checks fix GEODE-7884.  The SystemTimer changes, except for adding isCancelled(), are unrelated.  I made those changes so that I could test isCancelled() and add test coverage for SystemTimer.
hmm - I'll check into that.  Thanks Ernie
nice move breaking a dependency on an internal class
seems like we shouldn't call this a "swarm" any more

the name "swarmSet" is misleading. It's really a list of timers associated with this swarm. Furthermore, we blindly add the timer to the list, making it even less of a "set" than the mere name vs type discrepancy might indicate.
if duplicates do not hurt us, or if there is no possibility of duplicates, I suppose it's ok to not check for duplicates. Nevertheless. If we aren't eliding dupes tho, I feel like the name should change.
the name "swarmIterator" is misleading to me since it's iterating over timers. recommend name change
again the naming confuses me. It would make more sense to me if it was named something like "timers"
as above, I request renaming "swarmSet" to something like "timers"
Glad you got rid of this dead constructor. I disliked it because it was dead. But I hated it because it was not chained.

I see idleTask is never changed from non-null back to null ✓ OTOH since the variable is neither volatile nor guarded when we do the null-check, it is possible that if setIdleTimeoutTask() was called from a different thread than close() we could leak tasks.
I feel like maybe idleTask and ackTimeoutTask need to be volatile for this reason. Or maybe they need to be final and set from the constructor.

It's likely that these variables are set in one thread and then accessed in another, so I've followed your advice and made them volatile.  I've also added checks in the two timer tasks to cancel themselves if they see that the Connection they're monitoring has closed.  That should stop any remaining leaks.
